modules.description: This module generates reverse bindings for PKCS#11 operations by transforming the input module `X` into a structure that maps C-style function calls to OCaml values. It works with module signatures representing PKCS#11 APIs, converting them into a format suitable for dynamic linking and invocation. Concrete use cases include bridging OCaml applications with PKCS#11-compliant cryptographic libraries at runtime.

This module transforms PKCS#11 API signatures into OCaml values, enabling dynamic invocation of C-style cryptographic functions. It operates on module signatures that describe PKCS#11 operations, generating structures that map these to callable OCaml bindings. Use it to integrate OCaml applications with PKCS#11-compliant hardware security modules at runtime.

This module defines low-level bindings for PKCS#11 cryptographic operations, mapping C-style function signatures to OCaml. It works with abstract types representing cryptographic objects, sessions, and tokens, along with their associated metadata. Concrete use cases include initializing cryptographic providers, managing session handles, and performing raw cryptographic operations like signing and encryption.

This module defines reversed declarations for PKCS#11 constants and structures, primarily working with C-compatible enums and integer values. It maps low-level PKCS#11 numeric identifiers back to their symbolic names, facilitating debugging and logging of cryptographic operations. Use cases include interpreting return codes from PKCS#11 functions and converting object class or mechanism IDs into human-readable strings.
